## [Structure]{.vonrestoff} pages for ease of scanning {.center}

##  {#slide11-id .center data-menu-title="Wall of text"}

If I write a labyrinthine wall of text in small font without a heading, white-space or much punctuation using really long sentences and perhaps some cumbersome jargon the page is much harder to read and the key information that the user is looking for is harder to find; And if I put the most important information about how things can be improved using bullets, chunks, informative headings, bolding, highlights and callouts down here, it's likely the user will click away without even trying to read it, let alone finding what they came for when presented with a web page structured like this.

::: {.callout-important .unnumbered title="Key points for webpage structure" icon="true"}
Put the most important information at the top. Use chunks with informative headings. Use short sentences and simple vocabulary.

Important information could go in a callout like this.
:::

## Good web writing is<br>[easy to read and understand]{.vonrestoff} {.center}

## Writing by comparison {.center}

::: fragment
> There is a difference between waving and drowning.
:::

::: fragment
> Waving differs from drowning.[\*]{.highlight}

[\*]{.highlight}Bennett Rule: verbs instead of nouns
:::

## Good design is [accessible]{.vonrestoff} {.center}

## {.center}

:::{.callout-tip collapse="true" title="Common accessibility issues"}
These are the most common accessibility issues encountered by Digital Scholarship's Kiki Kuijjer:

-   Embedded links not distinguishable

-   Insufficient colour contrast

-   Alt-text missing

-   Not keyboard accessible

You can check your page for potential issues using an accessibility checker such as the [WAVE Web Accessibility Evaluation Tool](https://wave.webaim.org/).
:::

## Key messages {.center}

-   Design for [**what the user needs**]{.vonrestoff}

-   Structure your webpages so they are [**easy to scan**]{.vonrestoff}

-   Always look for ways to [**simplify and remove content**]{.vonrestoff}

## Subtraction Neglect Bias {#sec-subtraction-neglect-bias .center}

The bias towards adding instead of subtracting.

Consider removing words, slides, sections, ingredients, commitments or activities as a way to improve things.

::: {.callout-tip title="Antoine de Saint-Exupéry, 1939" icon="true" appearance="simple"}
*"...perfection is finally attained not when there is no longer anything to add, but when there is no longer anything to take away..."*

Source: [Tim Harford, Financial Times, 2024-01-05](https://www.ft.com/content/eb616ad3-e680-4161-9e20-53c4607cb609) (Link only accessible to FT subscribers)
:::
